text: i find it hard to believe with the current state of social media and mobile apps it's not easier to deliver a convincing message to get out the base...numbers showing turnout...there's got to be some way to engage with voters so you can show them your positions, solutions, plans as a candidate...some kind of game??  This charts just speak volumes to me  <http://imgur.com/TOGIbcP>

text: I’m working on a number of ways to get connected to the DNC (including folks who are likely to be in a position in power in the DNC)

okay not sure if this counts as political thing or civic tech thing so feel free to call me out if it’s in the wrong channel. 

but this is a pretty interesting discussion between amy goodman and john koza around the electoral college vs. popular vote. john koza offers some good points of action that we could take, mainly - contacting state legislators to sign the national popular vote bill

<http://www.democracynow.org/2016/11/11/millions_sign_onto_call_for_electoral>

attachments.title: Millions Sign Onto Call for Electoral College to Award the Presidency to Popular Vote Winner Clinton
attachments.text: The 2016 Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton leads the popular vote by hundreds of thousands of ballots, but she lost the Electoral College to Republican Donald Trump. The last time this type of outcome occurred was in the 2000 Bush vs. Gore presidential race. Meanwhile, electoral reform initiatives are underway to get states to adopt the National Popular Vote bill. The legislation could transform the way we elect the president of the United States. Under the compact for a national popular vote, states across the country have pledged to award their electoral votes to the presidential candidate who wins the nationwide popular vote. If enough states sign on, it would guarantee the presidency goes to the candidate who wins the most votes across the country. The compact will kick in only when enough states have signed on to reach a threshold of 270 electoral votes. We are joined by John Koza, chair of National Popular Vote.
attachments.fallback: Democracy Now!: Millions Sign Onto Call for Electoral College to Award the Presidency to Popular Vote Winner Clinton

text: another thing we could potentially bring up in convo with mr. blumenauer <@U026NB2U2> ^^
Thank you.
Regarding first post - the electors themselves can be written to.
Wonder how difficult it'd be to build a tool to make that process easier.
There's a wiki somewhere with all their contact info.

This book has some great ideas on how to become  engaged in our community - I learned of it in a college  course I took: <https://www.amazon.com/Roots-Radicals-Organizing-Action-Justice/dp/0826414990>

My friend Mike Bloomberg (not the mayor, his cousin's son) has a lot of contacts in the civic tech space. He unsuccessfully ran for state legislature in Mass. He would be available to chat with us next week on a Hangout to discuss how we might fund our ideas. His contacts are both in the private and public sectors.
